name: Ad Hominem
definition: Attacking the arguer instead of the argument.

name: Affirmative Conclusion from a Negative Premise
definition: A categorical syllogism has a positive conclusion, but at least one negative premise.

name: Affirming a Disjunct
definition: Concluding that one disjunct of a logical disjunction must be false because the other disjunct is true; A or B; A, therefore not B.

name: Affirming the Consequent
definition: The antecedent in an indicative conditional is claimed to be true because the consequent is true; if A, then B; B, therefore A.

name: Ambiguous Middle Term
definition: Using a middle term with multiple meanings.

name: Appeal to Accomplishment
definition: An assertion is deemed true or false based on the accomplishments of the proposer.

name: Appeal to Authority
definition: An assertion is deemed true because of the position or authority of the person asserting it.

name: Appeal to Consequences
definition: The conclusion is supported by a premise that asserts positive or negative consequences from some course of action in an attempt to distract from the initial discussion.

name: Appeal to Emotion
definition: Manipulating the emotions of the listener rather than using valid reasoning to obtain common agreement.

name: Appeal to Fear
definition: Generating distress, anxiety, cynicism, or prejudice towards the opponent in an argument.

name: Appeal to Flattery
definition: Using excessive or insincere praise to obtain common agreement.

name: Appeal to Motive
definition: Dismissing an idea by questioning the motives of its proposer.

name: Appeal to Nature
definition: Judgment is based solely on whether the subject of judgment is 'natural' or 'unnatural'.

name: Appeal to Novelty
definition: A proposal is claimed to be superior or better solely because it is new or modern.

name: Appeal to Pity
definition: Generating feelings of sympathy or mercy in the listener to obtain common agreement.

name: Appeal to Poverty
definition: Supporting a conclusion because the arguer is poor (or refuting because the arguer is wealthy).

name: Appeal to Probability
definition: Taking something for granted because it would probably be the case (or might possibly be the case).

name: Appeal to Ridicule
definition: Mocking or stating that the opponent's position is laughable to deflect from the merits of the opponent's argument.

name: Appeal to Spite
definition: Generating bitterness or hostility in the listener toward an opponent in an argument.

name: Appeal to the Stone
definition: Dismissing a claim as absurd without demonstrating proof for its absurdity.

name: Appeal to Tradition
definition: A conclusion supported solely because it has long been held to be true.

name: Appeal to Wealth
definition: Supporting a conclusion because the arguer is wealthy (or refuting because the arguer is poor).

name: Argument from Fallacy
definition: The assumption that, if a particular argument for a conclusion is fallacious, then the conclusion by itself is false.

name: Argument from Ignorance
definition: The belief that, because something is unknown, it is impossible to know anything about it.

name: Argument from Incredulity
definition: Dismissing a claim as false because it seems unbelievable or impossible to imagine, often phrased as 'I cannot imagine how this could be true; therefore, it must be false.'

name: Argument from Repetition
definition: Repeating an argument until nobody cares to discuss it anymore and referencing that lack of objection as evidence of support for the truth of the conclusion.

name: Argument from Silence
definition: Assuming that a claim is true based on the absence of textual or spoken evidence from an authoritative source, or vice versa.

name: Argument to Moderation
definition: Assuming that a compromise between two positions is always correct.

name: Argumentum ad Baculum
definition: An argument made through coercion or threats of force to support position.

name: Argumentum ad Populum
definition: A proposition is claimed to be true or good solely because a majority or many people believe it to be so.

name: Association Fallacy
definition: Arguing that because two things share (or are implied to share) some property, they are the same.

name: Baconian Fallacy
definition: Supposing that historians can obtain the 'whole truth' via induction from individual pieces of historical evidence.

name: Base Rate Fallacy
definition: Making a probability judgment based on conditional probabilities, without taking into account the effect of prior probabilities.

name: Begging the Question
definition: Using the conclusion of the argument in support of itself in a premise.

name: Bulverism
definition: Inferring why an argument is being used, associating it to some psychological reason, then assuming it is invalid as a result.

name: Chronological Snobbery
definition: A thesis is deemed incorrect because it was commonly held when something else, known to be false, was also commonly held.

name: Circular Reasoning
definition: The reasoner begins with what they are trying to end up with.

name: Circumstantial Ad Hominem
definition: Stating that the arguer's personal situation or perceived benefit from advancing a conclusion means that their conclusion is wrong.

name: Conjunction Fallacy
definition: The assumption that an outcome simultaneously satisfying multiple conditions is more probable than an outcome satisfying a single one of them.

name: Continuum Fallacy
definition: Improperly rejecting a claim for being imprecise.

name: Courtier's Reply
definition: A criticism is dismissed by claiming that the critic lacks sufficient knowledge, credentials, or training to credibly comment on the subject matter.

name: Cum Hoc Ergo Propter Hoc
definition: A faulty assumption that, because there is a correlation between two variables, one caused the other.

name: Definist Fallacy
definition: Defining a term used in an argument in a biased manner.

name: Definitional Retreat
definition: Changing the meaning of a word when an objection is raised.

name: Denying the Antecedent
definition: The consequent in an indicative conditional is claimed to be false because the antecedent is false; if A, then B; not A, therefore not B.

name: Divine Fallacy
definition: Arguing that, because something is so phenomenal or amazing, it must be the result of superior, divine, alien or paranormal agency.

name: Double Counting
definition: Counting events or occurrences more than once in probabilistic reasoning, which leads to the sum of the probabilities of all cases exceeding unity.

name: Ecological Fallacy
definition: Inferring about the nature of an entity based solely upon aggregate statistics collected for the group to which that entity belongs.

name: Equivocation
definition: Using a term with more than one meaning in a statement without specifying which meaning is intended.

name: Etymological Fallacy
definition: Assuming that the original or historical meaning of a word or phrase is necessarily similar to its actual present-day usage.

name: Existential Fallacy
definition: An argument that has a universal premise and a particular conclusion.

name: Fallacy of Accent
definition: Changing the meaning of a statement by not specifying on which word emphasis falls.

name: Fallacy of Composition
definition: Assuming that something true of part of a whole must also be true of the whole.

name: Fallacy of Division
definition: Assuming that something true of a composite thing must also be true of all or some of its parts.

name: Fallacy of Exclusive Premises
definition: A categorical syllogism that is invalid because both of its premises are negative.

name: Fallacy of Four Terms
definition: A categorical syllogism that has four terms.

name: Fallacy of Many Questions
definition: Someone asks a question that presupposes something that has not been proven or accepted by all the people involved.

name: Fallacy of Quoting Out of Context
definition: Selective excerpting of words from their original context to distort the intended meaning.

name: Fallacy of Relative Privation
definition: Dismissing an argument or complaint due to what are perceived to be more important problems.

name: Fallacy of the Single Cause
definition: It is assumed that there is one, simple cause of an outcome when in reality it may have been caused by a number of only jointly sufficient causes.

name: Fallacy of the Undistributed Middle
definition: The middle term in a categorical syllogism is not distributed.

name: False Attribution
definition: Appealing to an irrelevant, unqualified, unidentified, biased or fabricated source in support of an argument.

name: False Authority
definition: Using an expert of dubious credentials or using only one opinion to promote a product or idea.

name: False Dilemma
definition: Two alternative statements are given as the only possible options when, in reality, there are more.

name: False Equivalence
definition: Describing two or more statements as virtually equal when they are not.

name: Feedback Fallacy
definition: Believing in the objectivity of an evaluation to be used as the basis for improvement without verifying that the source of the evaluation is a disinterested party.

name: Furtive Fallacy
definition: Outcomes are asserted to have been caused by the malfeasance of decision makers.

name: Gambler's Fallacy
definition: The incorrect belief that separate, independent events can affect the likelihood of another random event. If a fair coin lands on heads 10 times in a row, the belief that it is 'due to the number of times it had previously landed on tails' is incorrect.

name: Garden of Forking Paths Fallacy
definition: Incorrect belief that a single experiment can not be subject to the multiple comparisons effect.

name: Genetic Fallacy
definition: A conclusion is suggested based solely on something or someone's origin rather than its current meaning or context.

name: Historian's Fallacy
definition: Assuming that decision-makers of the past had identical information as those subsequently analyzing the decision.

name: Historical Fallacy
definition: Believing that certain results occurred only because a specific process was performed, though said process may actually be unrelated to the results.

name: Homunculus Fallacy
definition: Using a 'middle-man' for explanation; this sometimes leads to regressive middle-men.

name: I'm Entitled to My Opinion
definition: A person discredits any opposition by claiming that they are entitled to their opinion.

name: If-by-Whiskey
definition: An argument that supports both sides of an issue by using terms that are emotionally sensitive and ambiguous.

name: Ignoring a Common Cause
definition: Failing to account for the possibility that two events might be caused by a third, unseen factor.

name: Ignoratio Elenchi
definition: An argument that may in itself be valid, but does not address the issue in question, also known as irrelevant conclusion or missing the point.

name: Illicit Major
definition: A categorical syllogism that is invalid because its major term is not distributed in the major premise but distributed in the conclusion.

name: Illicit Minor
definition: A categorical syllogism that is invalid because its minor term is not distributed in the minor premise but distributed in the conclusion.

name: Incomplete Comparison
definition: Insufficient information is provided to make a complete comparison.

name: Inflation of Conflict
definition: Arguing that, if experts in a field of knowledge disagree on a certain point within that field, no conclusion can be reached or that the legitimacy of that field of knowledge is questionable.

name: Intentionality Fallacy
definition: The insistence that the ultimate meaning of an expression must be consistent with the intention of the person from whom the communication originated.

name: Inverse Gambler's Fallacy
definition: The inverse of the gambler's fallacy. It is the incorrect belief that on the basis of an unlikely outcome, the process must have happened many times before.

name: Ipse Dixit
definition: A claim that is presented as true without support, as self-evidently true, or as dogmatically true.

name: Is-Ought Fallacy
definition: Deducing a conclusion about what ought to be, on the basis of what is.

name: Judgmental Language
definition: Using insulting or pejorative language in an argument.

name: Kettle Logic
definition: Using multiple, jointly inconsistent arguments to defend a position.

name: Loaded Label
definition: The use of evocative terms to support a conclusion, relying on the term's connotations to sway the argument towards a particular conclusion.

name: Logic Chopping Fallacy
definition: Focusing on trivial details of an argument, rather than the main point of the argumentation.

name: Magical Thinking
definition: Fallacious attribution of causal relationships between actions and events, often involving beliefs that ritual, prayer, sacrifice, and taboos will produce specific supernatural consequences.

name: Moving the Goalposts
definition: Argument in which evidence presented in response to a specific claim is dismissed and some other (often greater) evidence is demanded.

name: Prosecutor's Fallacy
definition: A low probability of false matches does not mean a low probability of some false match being found.

name: Proving Too Much
definition: An argument that results in an overly generalized conclusion.

name: Psychologist's Fallacy
definition: An observer presupposes the objectivity of their own perspective when analyzing a behavioral event.

name: Referential Fallacy
definition: Assuming that all words refer to existing things and that the meaning of words reside within the things they refer to.

name: Reification
definition: Treating an abstract belief or hypothetical construct as if it were a concrete, real event or physical entity.

name: Retrospective Determinism
definition: Believing that, because an event has occurred under some circumstance, the circumstance must have made the event inevitable.

name: Slippery Slope
definition: Asserting that a proposed, relatively small, first action will inevitably lead to a chain of related events resulting in a significant and negative event.

name: Special Pleading
definition: The arguer attempts to cite something as an exemption to a generally accepted rule or principle without justifying the exemption.

name: Questionable Cause
definition: A general type of error with many variants, primarily based on the confusion of association with causation, either by inappropriately deducing (or rejecting) causation or a broader failure to properly investigate the cause of an observed effect.

name: Post Hoc Ergo Propter Hoc
definition: X happened, then Y happened; therefore X caused Y.

name: Wrong Direction
definition: Cause and effect are reversed. The cause is said to be the effect and vice versa.

name: Regression Fallacy
definition: Ascribes cause where none exists. The flaw is failing to account for natural fluctuations. It is frequently a special kind of post hoc fallacy.

name: P-hacking
definition: Belief in the significance of a result, not realizing that multiple comparisons or experiments have been run and only the most significant were published.

name: Appeal to the Stone
definition: Dismissing a claim as absurd without demonstrating proof for its absurdity.

name: Argument from Ignorance
definition: The belief that, because something is unknown, it is impossible to know anything about it.

name: Argument from Incredulity
definition: Dismissing a claim as false because it seems unbelievable or impossible to imagine, often phrased as 'I cannot imagine how this could be true; therefore, it must be false.'

name: Argument from Repetition
definition: Repeating an argument until nobody cares to discuss it anymore and referencing that lack of objection as evidence of support for the truth of the conclusion.

name: Argument from Silence
definition: Assuming that a claim is true based on the absence of textual or spoken evidence from an authoritative source, or vice versa.

name: Ignoratio Elenchi
definition: An argument that may in itself be valid, but does not address the issue in question, also known as irrelevant conclusion or missing the point.

name: Red Herring
definition: Introducing a second argument in response to the first argument that is irrelevant and draws attention away from the original topic.

name: Poisoning the Well
definition: Presenting adverse information about a target person with the intention of discrediting everything that the target person says.

name: Appeal to Motive
definition: Dismissing an idea by questioning the motives of its proposer.

name: Tone Policing
definition: Focusing on emotion behind (or resulting from) a message rather than the message itself as a discrediting tactic.

name: Traitorous Critic Fallacy
definition: A critic's perceived affiliation is portrayed as the underlying reason for the criticism and the critic is asked to stay away from the issue altogether.

name: Appeal to Authority
definition: An assertion is deemed true because of the position or authority of the person asserting it.

name: Appeal to Accomplishment
definition: An assertion is deemed true or false based on the accomplishments of the proposer.

name: Courtier's Reply
definition: A criticism is dismissed by claiming that the critic lacks sufficient knowledge, credentials, or training to credibly comment on the subject matter.

name: Appeal to Consequences
definition: The conclusion is supported by a premise that asserts positive or negative consequences from some course of action in an attempt to distract from the initial discussion.

name: Appeal to Emotion
definition: Manipulating the emotions of the listener rather than using valid reasoning to obtain common agreement.

name: Appeal to Fear
definition: Generating distress, anxiety, cynicism, or prejudice towards the opponent in an argument.

name: Appeal to Flattery
definition: Using excessive or insincere praise to obtain common agreement.

name: Appeal to Pity
definition: Generating feelings of sympathy or mercy in the listener to obtain common agreement.

name: Appeal to Ridicule
definition: Mocking or stating that the opponent's position is laughable to deflect from the merits of the opponent's argument.

name: Appeal to Spite
definition: Generating bitterness or hostility in the listener toward an opponent in an argument.

name: Judgmental Language
definition: Using insulting or pejorative language in an argument.

name: Pooh-pooh
definition: Stating that an opponent's argument is unworthy of consideration.

name: Style over Substance
definition: Embellishing an argument with compelling language, exploiting a bias towards the esthetic qualities of an argument.

name: Wishful Thinking
definition: Arguing for a course of action by the listener according to what might be pleasing to imagine rather than according to evidence or reason.

name: Appeal to Nature
definition: Judgment is based solely on whether the subject of judgment is 'natural' or 'unnatural'.

name: Appeal to Novelty
definition: A proposal is claimed to be superior or better solely because it is new or modern.

name: Appeal to Poverty
definition: Supporting a conclusion because the arguer is poor (or refuting because the arguer is wealthy).

name: Appeal to Tradition
definition: A conclusion supported solely because it has long been held to be true.

name: Appeal to Wealth
definition: Supporting a conclusion because the arguer is wealthy (or refuting because the arguer is poor).

name: Argumentum ad Baculum
definition: An argument made through coercion or threats of force to support position.

name: Argumentum ad Populum
definition: A proposition is claimed to be true or good solely because a majority or many people believe it to be so.

name: Association Fallacy
definition: Arguing that because two things share (or are implied to share) some property, they are the same.

name: Logic Chopping Fallacy
definition: Focusing on trivial details of an argument, rather than the main point of the argumentation.

name: Ipse Dixit
definition: A claim that is presented as true without support, as self-evidently true, or as dogmatically true.

name: Bulverism
definition: Inferring why an argument is being used, associating it to some psychological reason, then assuming it is invalid as a result.

name: Chronological Snobbery
definition: A thesis is deemed incorrect because it was commonly held when something else, known to be false, was also commonly held.

name: Fallacy of Relative Privation
definition: Dismissing an argument or complaint due to what are perceived to be more important problems.

name: Genetic Fallacy
definition: A conclusion is suggested based solely on something or someone's origin rather than its current meaning or context.

name: I'm Entitled to My Opinion
definition: A person discredits any opposition by claiming that they are entitled to their opinion.

name: Moralistic Fallacy
definition: Inferring factual conclusions from evaluative premises, in violation of fact-value distinction.

name: Naturalistic Fallacy
definition: Inferring evaluative conclusions from purely factual premises in violation of fact-value distinction.

name: Is-Ought Fallacy
definition: Deducing a conclusion about what ought to be, on the basis of what is.

name: Naturalistic Fallacy Fallacy
definition: Inferring an impossibility to infer any instance of ought from is from the general invalidity of is-ought fallacy.

name: Straw Man Fallacy
definition: Refuting an argument different from the one actually under discussion, while not recognizing or acknowledging the distinction.

name: Texas Sharpshooter Fallacy
definition: Improperly asserting a cause to explain a cluster of data.

name: Tu Quoque
definition: Stating that a position is false, wrong, or should be disregarded because its proponent fails to act consistently in accordance with it.

name: Two Wrongs Make a Right
definition: Assuming that, if one wrong is committed, another wrong will rectify it.

name: Vacuous Truth
definition: A claim that is technically true but meaningless, in the form no A in B has C, when there is no A in B.
